Nel frattempo, i suoi discorsi politici nazionali tennero saldo il paese e l'opinione degli alleati. Si dice che Hitler odiasse più Roosevelt che Stalin o Churchill... una lode davvero notevole.[PARAGRAPH:2]Come leader militare Roosevelt era sicuramente meno dotato e gli Stati Uniti fecero alcuni errori strategici iniziale che si sarebbero potuti evitare. Tuttavia, imparò presto dai propri errori e, al termine della sua vita, la macchina militare Americana era la più potente che il mondo avesse mai visto.[PARAGRAPH:2]Roosevelt morì nel 1945, poco prima della fine della guerra. La sua eredità nel campo sociale e nella cooperazione internazionale dominarono la politica degli Stati Uniti per i successivi cinquant'anni.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Franklin Roosevelt[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Presidente de los Estados Unidos[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] 1882 - 1945 d. C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]A Franklin Delano Roosevelt, 32º Presidente de los Estados Unidos, se le conoce sobre todo por haber dirigido los destinos de su país durante la Gran Depresión y por haberlo llevado a la victoria en la Segunda Guerra Mundial. Paralítico por culpa de la polio a la edad de 39 años, Roosevelt hizo gala de un valor y una decisión invencibles para sobreponerse a su enfermedad y alcanzar sus metas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Era un hombre lleno de contradicciones. Aunque rico y poderoso, era querido por los pobres y desposeídos, mientras que los ricos y poderosos como él lo despreciaban, tomándolo por socialista. Llegó al poder con un programa aislacionista, pero odiaba el fascismo y la opresión y trabajó incansable y discretamente para apoyar a Inglaterra y conseguir que Estados Unidos participara en la Segunda Guerra Mundial.[PARAGRAPH:2]Cuando llegó a presidente por primera vez, en 1932, el país estaba sumido en una terrible crisis. Muchos bancos habían cerrado y numerosas empresas habían ido a la quiebra. Millones de personas estaban desempleadas y en la miseria. Para resolver esta situación, Roosevelt promulgó una serie de medidas conocidas en su conjunto como "New Deal": un amplio programa encaminado a propiciar la recuperación de los negocios y la agricultura, y a ayudar a los parados y a quienes corrían el riesgo de perder sus negocios, granjas y hogares.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mientras tanto, la Depresión se extendía por el planeta entero, que en su mayor parte estaba sumiéndose en el caos. Japón atacó a China, mientras los dos grandes dictadores, Hitler y Stalin, amenazaban con apoderarse de Europa. Los Estados Unidos habían adoptado una política de aislacionismo desde el final de la Primera Guerra Mundial y el fracaso de la Liga de las Naciones, y pocos políticos norteamericanos se atrevían a apoyar una intervención. Roosevelt tampoco lo hizo y, de hecho, se presentó a las elecciones con un programa aislacionista.[PARAGRAPH:2]Sin embargo, estaba sinceramente convencido de que el país tendría que implicarse en el conflicto de un modo u otro (aborrecía el fascismo y el totalitarismo) y temía que, si nadie lo impedía, el poder de Alemania, Rusia y Japón crecería hasta el punto de que podrían vencer toda oposición... incluida, algún día, la de EE. UU. Por tanto, hizo cuanto estuvo en su mano por preparar al país para el inminente conflicto, incrementando de forma espectacular las dimensiones de sus fuerzas armadas, que habían quedado en un estado penoso tras el fin de la Primera Guerra Mundial. Además, prestó toda la ayuda políticamente factible a Gran Bretaña, a la que no consideraba preparada para enfrentarse a la maquinaria bélica alemana. Al mismo tiempo, se esforzó en conseguir que la opinión pública americana adoptara una política más favorable a la intervención.[PARAGRAPH:2]No está claro si lo habría conseguido de no ser por el ataque japonés contra Pearl Harbour. Aunque el ataque causó grandes pérdidas, Pearl Harbour sirvió para "despertar a un gigante dormido", y finalmente la ciudadanía comprendió el peligro al que se exponía. Y, cuando, poco después, Alemania cometió la increíble torpeza estratégica de declararle la guerra a los Estados Unidos, Roosevelt pudo poner todo el inmenso poderío militar e industrial del país al servicio de la victoria.[PARAGRAPH:2]Durante la guerra, demostró ser un maestro de la política internacional. La alianza entre Gran Bretaña, la Unión Soviética y EE. UU. era como mínimo inestable, y la diplomacia de la que hizo gala en sus tratos con Stalin y Churchill consiguió que las cosas marcharan bien (relativamente). Mientras tanto sus, "conversaciones junto al fuego" conseguían que siguiera contando con el respaldo del país y con el apoyo de todo el mundo a la causa de los aliados. Se dice que Hitler lo odiaba aún más que a Churchill o Stalin: qué mejor elogio que éste.[PARAGRAPH:2]Como jefe militar, Roosevelt no demostró la misma capacidad y, al principio de la guerra, EE. UU. cometió algunos errores que podrían haberse evitado. Sin embargo, fue aprendiendo rápidamente y, al morir, EE. UU. poseía la maquinaria bélica más poderosa de toda la historia.[PARAGRAPH:2]Roosevelt murió en 1945, poco antes del fin de la guerra. Su legado de bienestar social y cooperación internacional dominaría la política norteamericana durante el medio siglo siguiente.

TEXT.English: [H1]Salah ad-Din Yusuf ibn Ayyub[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of Egypt and Syria[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c.1137 - 1193 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Saladin was a Kurdish Muslim warrior and self-proclaimed Sultan of Egypt. During his life he was the Defender of Islam and great opponent to the Crusaders.[PARAGRAPH:2]Of Kurdish descent, born in Mesopotamia, Saladin grew to become a religious warrior. During his youth he studied Sunni theology for ten years and then accompanied his uncle during his battles to conquer Egypt (ca. 1167). After his uncle died, Saladin succeeded him as vizier (minister of state) of Egypt, and he eventually proclaimed himself sultan (sovereign).[PARAGRAPH:2]During his reign Saladin conquered portions of North Africa, Yemen, Syria and Palestine. He mustered a large force of Muslims to defeat the Christian occupiers and retake the city of Jerusalem. He fought off a spirited attempt to retake the city (the Third Crusade) in 1189; in 1192 Saladin signed a treaty with the Crusaders, leaving them just a small strip of land in Syria on the coast of the Mediterranean.[PARAGRAPH:2]Saladin had a richly-deserved reputation for generosity and chivalry in battle. He treated his prisoners honorably, and was a man of his word. He was greatly admired by his European opponents, who barely acknowledged other Muslims as human.
TEXT.French: [H1]Saladin[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan ayyoubide d'Egypte[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD]vers 1137 - 1193 ap. J.-C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Saladin est un guerrier musulman kurde qui s'est autoproclamé sultan d'Egypte. Pendant toute sa vie, il défend l'Islam et s'oppose aux croisés.[PARAGRAPH:2]D'origine kurde et né en Mésopotamie, Saladin devient rapidement un guerrier religieux. Dans sa jeunesse, il étudie la théologie sunnite pendant dix ans, puis accompagne son oncle lors de sa conquête de l'Egypte (vers 1167). A la mort de son oncle, Saladin lui succède comme vizir d'Egypte (ministre d'Etat) et finit par s'autoproclamer sultan (souverain).[PARAGRAPH:2]Au cours de son règne, Saladin entreprend de nombreuses conquêtes en Afrique du Nord, au Yémen, en Syrie et en Palestine. Il rassemble une importante armée de musulmans pour défaire les occupants chrétiens et reprendre la ville de Jérusalem. Il lutte contre une violente tentative de reprise de la ville en 1189 (troisième croisade) et il signe, en 1192, un traité avec les croisés leur laissant juste une petite bande de terre en Syrie, sur la côte méditerranéenne.[PARAGRAPH:2]Saladin a une réputation amplement méritée de générosité et de courtoisie au combat. Il traite ses prisonniers convenablement et est un homme de parole. Il fait l'objet d'une vive admiration de la part de ses opposants européens qui peinent à reconnaître les autres musulmans comme des humains.
TEXT.German: [H1]Saladin[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Ayyubid Sultan von Ägypten[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] Um 1137 - 1193 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Saladin, ein kurdischer Krieger, war der selbst ernannte Sultan Ägyptens. Als "Verteidiger des Islam" war er der mächtigste Gegenspieler der Kreuzritter.[PARAGRAPH:2]Saladin wurde in Mesopotamien geboren und zum Krieger erzogen. In seiner Jugend studierte er zehn Jahre lang die sunnitische Theologie, bevor er sich (um 1167) seinem Onkel anschloss, um Ägypten zu erobern. Nach dem Tod seines Onkels nahm Saladin dessen Platz als Wesir (Minister) Ägyptens ein und ernannte sich schließlich zum Sultan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Während seiner Herrschaft eroberte er große Teile Nordafrikas, den Jemen, Syrien und Palästina, bevor er das von Christen besetzte Jerusalem zurückeroberte. 1189 schlug er die Ritter des 3. Kreuzzugs zurück. 1192 unterzeichnete er einen Friedensvertrag, der den Christen einen schmalen Landstrich an der syrischen Mittelmeerküste zusprach.[PARAGRAPH:2]Saladin galt als großmütiger und ritterlicher Kämpfer. Er behandelte seine Gefangenen mit Würde und stand zu seinem Wort. Seine christlichen Gegner bewunderten ihn, obwohl die Muslime in ihren Augen keine Menschen waren.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Saladino[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultano Ayyubid d'Egitto[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vissuto nel:[\BOLD] ca. 1137 - 1193 d.C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Saladino era un guerriero Kurdish Muslim e un sultano d'Egitto auto-proclamato. Durante la sua vita, fu il Difensore dell'Islamismo e il grande avversario dei Crociati.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nato in Mesopotamia e di discendenza Curda, Saladino divenne presto un guerriero religioso. Durante la sua giovinezza studiò la teologia Sannita per dieci anni e accompagnò suo zio nelle sue battaglie per la conquista dell'Egitto (1167 d. C.) Alla morte dello zio, Saladino gli succedette come visir (ministro di stato) dell'Egitto e infine si proclamò sultano (governante).[PARAGRAPH:2]Nel corso del suo regno, Saladino conquistò parti del Nord Africa, dello Yemen, della Siria e della Palestina. Riunì un grande esercito di Musulmani per sconfiggere le forze occupanti Cristiane e riprendere la città di Gerusalemme. Nel 1189, lotto vigorosamente per cercare di riconquistare la città (durante la Terza Crociata) e nel 1192 firmò un trattato con i Crociati, lasciandogli soltanto una piccola striscia di terra in Siria, sulla costa Mediterranea.[PARAGRAPH:2]Saladino aveva una meritata reputazione di persona generosa e cortese in battaglia: egli trattava onorevolmente i suoi prigionieri ed era un uomo di parola. Era molto ammirato dai suoi avversari europei, che difficilmente riconoscevano gli altri Musulmani come esseri umani.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Saladino[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultán ayubí de Egipto[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] c.1137 - 1193 d. C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Saladino fue un guerrero kurdo y musulmán que se proclamó sultán de Egipto. Durante su vida se erigió en defensor del Islam y fue el gran enemigo de los cruzados.[PARAGRAPH:2]Kurdo de ascendencia y nacido en Mesopotamia, Saladino se convirtió en un guerrero religioso. En su juventud estudió la teología suní durante 10 años y luego acompañó a su tío en la conquista de Egipto (ca. 1167). Tras la muerte de éste, Saladino lo sucedió como visir (ministro de estado) de Egipto, y finalmente acabó por proclamarse sultán (soberano).[PARAGRAPH:2]Durante su reinado conquistó parte de África del norte, el Yemen, Siria y Palestina. Reunió un gran ejército musulmán para derrotar a los conquistadores cristianos y recuperar la ciudad de Jerusalén. En 1189 repelió un poderoso ataque encaminado a la reconquista de Jerusalén (la Tercera Cruzada); en 1192, firmó un tratado con los cruzados que les permitía conservar una pequeña franja de tierra en Siria, en la costa mediterránea.[PARAGRAPH:2]Saladino gozaba de una merecida reputación por su generosidad y su caballerosidad en el campo de batalla. Trataba a sus prisioneros honorablemente y siempre cumplía su palabra. Contaba con la admiración de sus adversarios europeos, para quienes el resto de los musulmanes apenas eran seres humanos.

TEXT.English: [H1]Jose Francisco de San Martin[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]President of Peru[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1778 - 1850 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Groomed from a young age for the life of a soldier, Jose de San Martin would grow to lead the Peruvian and Chilean people to independence from Spain.[PARAGRAPH:2]Born in Argentina, but raised in Spain, by the age of 11, Jose de San Martin was already a member of the Spanish armed forces. In the Peninsular War between Spain and France in 1808, San Martin began as an aide to the Spanish leadership; by war's end he had attained the rank of Lieutenant Colonel.[PARAGRAPH:2]In the midst of the war, the Spanish king abdicated from power to be replaced by an appointment of the opposing French. The citizens of Argentina, upon hearing of the Spanish government's state of disarray, decided that there would be no better time to declare independence. When news of the Argentine revolution reached him, San Martin elected to support the rebels' cause, leaving Spain for the New World. Upon his arrival, he was immediately recruited by the rebel forces to begin mustering and training an elite regiment. His regiment, known as the Mounted Grenadiers, became some of the finest troops South America had to offer.[PARAGRAPH:2]Once his troops were ready, the normally reserved drillmaster suggested a daring move - marching an army from Argentina to Chile through the peaks of the Andes. His plan was regarded as madness by many, but San Martin managed to muster more than enough brave souls to join him in the endeavor. Dividing his forces into six columns for easier travel through the difficult terrain, San Martin planned for each column to arrive within two days of one another, a highly unlikely prospect given the extreme terrain and great danger that lay ahead.[PARAGRAPH:2]But on February 12, nearly all four thousand troops stepped out from the shadows of the Andes onto the plains of Chacabuco, prepared to face the numerically superior Spanish forces. Despite having just traversed some of the most inhospitable terrain on earth, San Martin's "Army of the Andes," soundly defeated the Royalists. They then marched on the Chilean capital of Santiago, taking the city with little fuss. Despite what many thought to be a crushing loss on the field of Tacla roughly a month later, Chile was to remain in the hands of San Martin and his revolutionary followers.[PARAGRAPH:2]The citizens of Chile attempted to appoint San Martin governor of their colony, but he refused. He had his sights set on the bastion of Spanish power in South America - Lima, Peru. San Martin took his forces north, offering the Spanish forces in Lima the opportunity to surrender and set up a new constitutional government. Their refusal sealed their fate - in 1821, San Martin marched into Lima, taking the city for the rebels. He was soon proclaimed the first President of Peru.[PARAGRAPH:2]Small pockets of Spanish forces remained scattered throughout the Peruvian countryside and in order to ensure their removal, San Martin requested a conference with Simon Bolivar, the Liberator of the north whose military zone of influence overlapped that of San Martin.[PARAGRAPH:2]The two met in the city of Guayaquil, Ecuador in 1822. What they discussed is unknown, but the result is - on that day San Martin stepped down from his position, leaving the fate of South America in the hands of Bolivar. San Martin had previously displayed a wavering of passion for his cause, but it took the words of Bolivar to force a decision. Upon stepping down, San Martin settled with his wife and children on a farm in Argentina for two years before migrating to Europe, where he spent the remainder of his days moving from country to country in order to escape the numerous revolutions sweeping the continent at the time. He died in France in 1850.

[H1]Antonio de Padua María Severino López de Santa Anna y Pérez de Lebrón[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]President of Mexico[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1794 - 1876 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Santa Anna's normal loyalty would be to ally with the wealthy and privileged, but his immediate concern was to be on the winning side in any battle. Switching allegiance never troubled him. Santa Anna declared himself retired, "unless my country needs me". He decided he was needed when Anastasio Bustamante led a coup, overthrowing and killing President Vicente Guerrero. Santa Anna was elected president in 1833.[PARAGRAPH:2]Gómez Farías did many reforms, introducing antimilitary and anticlergical reforms. He reduced the size of the army and worked hard to root out corruption in the military. He also changed some rules reflecting the power of the Church. Clergymen would be allowed to preach only for religious matters. He altered the education as a fully secular system.[PARAGRAPH:2] The mandatory tax for the support of the Church was abolished. These drastic reforms angered many of the powerful among the military, wealthy landowners, and the Catholic Church. When there was rebellion and violence against the reform that Farias had made, Santa Anna changed his side, again. Santa Anna reversed his support for the liberals and joined the conservatives, dismissed Farías, declared the Constitution suspended, disbanded the Congress, and worked to concentrate power in the central government. This was applauded by some conservatives, but met with considerable disapproval from other sectors. He established a Catholic, centralist dictatorship and replaced the Constitution of 1824(the one that Farias established), with a new document, called The Seven Laws. the Constitution of 1836. The regime was a centralized dictatorship led by the military.[PARAGRAPH:2]Several states went into open rebellion: Coahuila y Tejas, San Luis Potosí, Querétaro, Durango, Guanajuato, Michoacán, Yucatán, Jalisco, Nuevo León, Tamaulipas and Zacatecas. Several of these states formed their own governments, the Republic of the Rio Grande, the Republic of Yucatan, and the Republic of Texas. Only the Texans defeated Santa Anna and retained their independence. They and their allies from the United States declared independence from Mexico. Their fierce resistance was possibly fueled by reprisals Santa Anna committed against his defeated enemies.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Zacatecan militia, the largest and best supplied of the Mexican states, led by Francisco Garcia, was well armed with .753 caliber British 'Brown Bess' muskets and Baker .61 rifles. After two hours of combat, on 12 May 1835, the Santa Anna's "Army of Operations" defeated the Zacatecan militia and took almost 3,000 prisoners. Santa Anna allowed his army to ransack Zacatecas for forty-eight hours. After defeating Zacatecas, he planned to move on to Coahuila y Tejas.

[H1]Shaka[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Zulu Chieftain[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1787 - 1828[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Shaka was a Zulu chieftain who is credited with transforming his tribe from one of many insignificant entities into the terror of southern Africa. Many historians consider him to be a military genius. During his tumultuous lifetime Shaka caused revolutionary changes to Zulu society and profoundly altered the history of his tribe forever.[PARAGRAPH:2]Shaka was born sometime around 1787 to Chief Senzangakona of the Zulus and the woman Nandi, who was the daughter of a nearby chieftain. In his early days, Shaka served as a warrior for another local chieftain named Digiswayo. When Shaka's father died around 1816, Digiswayo helped Shaka claim the chiefdom of the Zulus for himself. Shaka then murdered his half brother to secure his new position.[PARAGRAPH:2] Once Shaka had control over the Zulu, he began a series of reforms that would transform the Zulu military into the region's most powerful fighting force. First, Shaka replaced the traditional "assegai" (a javelin-like throwing spear) with the "lklwa," a short spear intended for stabbing. He also equipped his men with larger and heavier shields. This new weaponry allowed Shaka to dramatically alter his army's battle tactics, changing the very nature of warfare in the region.[PARAGRAPH:2]Before Shaka, among the tribes of southern Africa, combat was in large ritualized. The two forces would stand apart from one-another, chanting loudly and clashing their shields while hurling their spears at each other. Eventually one side's resolve would falter and they'd retreat, leaving the other side in possession of the field. Few warriors on either side were killed, and the battles rarely provided decisive results.[PARAGRAPH:2]With his military reforms, Shaka was to change all that. Shaka taught his army to close with the opponents' forces, fighting in hand-to-hand combat, where the new weaponry and shields provided Shaka's forces with a decisive advantage over their foes. Shaka invented a tactical formation called the "buffalo horns," under which his army had large wings (or horns) extending to the right and left of the main force. The main force would engage the enemy directly, while the horns outflanked the foe on left and right. Surrounded on three sides and facing a foe armed with better weaponry and shields, few armies could stand up to the Zulu attack.[PARAGRAPH:2]With the most powerful army in the region, Shaka unleashed a reign of terror upon the unsuspecting neighboring tribes of southern Africa. Shaka began his conquests with limited forces. However, through skilled diplomacy and the judicious use of assassination, he rapidly set up a system of alliances and vassal rulers to extend his control over a wide range of territory, rapidly increasing the forces under his command. Those who opposed him were slaughtered without mercy. Within a decade tribes began migrating out of the area, fleeing the Zulus in all directions. This movement of peoples has become known as Mfecane, or "the scattering."[PARAGRAPH:2]Although a great conqueror, Shaka was not an effective domestic ruler. His brutal regime was quite unpopular, and several assassinations and coups were attempted. Eventually, one of them succeeded, and in 1828 Shaka was mortally wounded by his two half-brothers. As he lay dying, Shaka is said to have told his half-brothers that they would not rule long, and that the white men would soon take the Zulu lands. Unfortunately for the Zulus, Shaka spoke truthfully, and within seventy years the Zulu would be conquered by the British.[PARAGRAPH:2]It is interesting to speculate what would have been the result if Shaka has still been alive when the British invaded Zululand. Shaka was a great military innovator, and it's possible that he would have much earlier understood the power of the British rifles, and he might have quickly tried to adopt the weapons for his own troops. However, the fact remains that his people would still have had no industrial base and little ability to import such weapons. He might have chosen to avoid open-field battle and adopt guerilla tactics; while this would have caused the invaders much more grief, it is likely that in the end he too would have been defeated by the British military-industrial juggernaut.
TEXT.French: [H1]Chaka[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chef zoulou[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD] 1787 - 1828[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Chaka est un chef zoulou qui a fait de sa tribu, une simple entité parmi de nombreuses autres, la terreur du Sud de l'Afrique. De nombreux historiens le considèrent comme un génie militaire. Pendant sa vie tumultueuse, Chaka met en oeuvre des changements révolutionnaires dans la société zoulou et modifie profondément et durablement l'histoire de sa tribu.[PARAGRAPH:2]Chaka est né vers 1787 de l'union du chef des Zoulous Senza Ngakona et de Nandi, fille d'un chef voisin. Au début de sa vie, Chaka est guerrier pour le compte d'un autre chef local nommé Dinguiswayo. A la mort de son père en 1816, Dinguiswayo aide Chaka à devenir chef des Zoulous à son tour. Chaka assassine ensuite son demi-frère pour protéger sa nouvelle fonction.[PARAGRAPH:2]Une fois qu'il contrôle les Zoulous, Chaka lance plusieurs réformes destinées à faire de l'armée zoulou la force militaire la plus puissante de la région. Il remplace tout d'abord la traditionnelle "assegai" (une lance ressemblant à un javelot) par la "lklwa", une courte lance servant à poignarder. Il fournit également à ses hommes des boucliers plus grands et plus lourds. Ce nouvel armement permet à Chaka de modifier profondément les tactiques militaires de son armée, transformant la nature même de la guerre dans cette région.[PARAGRAPH:2]Avant l'arrivée au pouvoir de Chaka, le combat entre les tribus d'Afrique méridionale est largement ritualisé. Les deux forces se tiennent à distance l'une de l'autre, chantant bruyamment et entrechoquant leurs boucliers tout en projetant leurs lances. La détermination de l'une des parties finit par s'user et elle se retire, abandonnant le territoire à l'autre partie. Dans chaque camp, quelques guerriers sont tués et les batailles ne donnent que rarement des résultats décisifs.[PARAGRAPH:2]Par ses réformes militaires, Chaka va modifier tout ce rituel. Il apprend à son armée à se rapprocher de ses ennemis et à mener des combats au corps à corps, dans lesquels les nouvelles armes et les boucliers donnent aux forces de Chaka un avantage décisif sur leurs ennemis. Chaka invente une nouvelle formation tactique appelée "tête de buffle", dans laquelle son armée forme de grandes ailes (les cornes) à droite et à gauche de la force principale. Celle-ci engage le combat directement avec l'ennemi alors que les cornes le débordent sur la droite et la gauche. Entourées sur trois côtés et confrontées à un ennemi armé d'armes et de boucliers plus performants, peu d'armées résistent aux attaques zoulous.[PARAGRAPH:2]Disposant de la plus puissante armée de la région, Chaka déclenche la terreur dans les tribus voisines peu méfiantes du Sud de l'Afrique. Il entame ses conquêtes avec des forces réduites. Cependant, grâce à son talent de diplomate et au recours avisé aux assassinats, il met rapidement en place un système d'alliances et de dirigeants vassaux qui permet d'étendre son contrôle sur un vaste territoire, augmentant rapidement l'effectif des forces se trouvant sous son commandement. Ses opposants sont tués sans merci. En l'espace d'une décennie, les tribus émigrent en dehors de cette zone, fuyant dans toutes les directions pour échapper aux Zoulous. Ces mouvements migratoires sont connus sous l'appellation Mfecane, qui signifie "dispersion".[PARAGRAPH:2]S'il est un grand conquérant, Chaka n'est pas un dirigeant compétent. Son régime cruel n'est pas très populaire et plusieurs tentatives d'assassinats et de coups d'Etat sont recensées. L'une d'elles finit par réussir et, en 1828, Skaka est mortellement blessé par ses deux demi-frères. On raconte que sur son lit de mort, il aurait raconté à ses demi-frères qu'ils ne règneraient pas longtemps et que les Blancs s'empareraient prochainement des territoires zoulous. Malheureusement pour les Zoulous, Chaka disait vrai et en 70 ans, les Zoulous sont conquis par les Britanniques.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il est intéressant de se demander ce qu'aurait pu être l'issue des combats s'il avait toujours été en vie lorsque les Britanniques envahirent le Zululand. En tant que grand innovateur militaire, Chaka aurait probablement compris plus rapidement le pouvoir des fusils britanniques et aurait essayé d'adopter ces armes pour ses propres troupes. Il n'en demeure pas moins que son peuple n'aurait pas disposé d'une base industrielle et qu'il aurait eu peu de possibilités d'importer de telles armes. Il aurait certainement évité un combat en terrain découvert, privilégiant la guérilla. Ces tactiques auraient rendu la tâche plus difficile pour les envahisseurs mais il est probable qu'en dernier lieu, il aurait lui-même été battu par le poids militaro-industriel écrasant des Britanniques.
TEXT.German: [H1]Shaka[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Zulu-Häuptling[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 1787 - 1828[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Shaka war ein Zulu-Häuptling, der sein Volk aus seinem unauffälligen Dasein als einer von vielen Stämmen zum Schreckgespenst Südafrikas machte. Viele Historiker halten ihn für ein militärisches Genie. Während seines turbulenten Lebens führte Shaka revolutionäre Neuerungen in der gesellschaftlichen Struktur der Zulu ein und änderte die Geschichte seines Stammes für alle Zeiten.[PARAGRAPH:2]Shaka wurde um 1787 als Sohn des Zulu-Häuptlings Senzangakhona und der Stammesfrau Nandi geboren, der Tochter des Häuptlings eines Nachbarstammes. Da er von seinem Vater verleugnet und verstoßen wurde, verbrachte Shaka seine Jugend als Krieger für einen anderen Häuptling namens Dingiswayo. Als Shakas Vater um 1816 starb, half ihm Dingiswayo, den Thron der Zulu zu besteigen. Und damit seine neue Position auf keinen Fall gefährdet werden konnte, ermordete Shaka sicherheitshalber sogar seinen Halbbruder.[PARAGRAPH:2]Nach seiner Machtergreifung setzte Shaka eine Reihe von Neuerungen bei den Zulu durch, welche die Zulu-Krieger zur mächtigsten Streitmacht der Region machen sollten. Als Erstes ersetzte er den traditionellen "Assegai" (eine Art Wurfspieß) durch einen kürzeren Stoßspeer, den "Iklwa". Außerdem stattete er seine Krieger auch mit größeren, schwereren Schilden aus. Diese neue Ausrüstung ermöglichte es Shaka, die Kampftaktiken seiner Armee und damit die gesamte Art der Kriegsführung in der ganzen Region dramatisch zu ändern.[PARAGRAPH:2]Vor Shaka waren die Kämpfe der Stämme in Südafrika im Großen und Ganzen eher ritueller Natur gewesen: Die beiden Kampfparteien standen weit voneinander entfernt, gaben laute rhythmische Gesänge von sich und klapperten mit ihren Schilden, während sie ihre Speere aufeinander zuwarfen. Am Ende geriet die Entschlossenheit eines der beiden Widersacher derart ins Wanken, dass er den Rückzug antrat und dem anderen das Feld überließ. Dementsprechend kamen auf beiden Seiten nur wenige Krieger tatsächlich ums Leben und die Kämpfe brachten selten entscheidende Ergebnisse.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mit seinen militärischen Reformen änderte Shaka all das grundlegend. Er lehrte seine Krieger, sich dem Gegner bis in den Nahkampfbereich anzunähern, in dem ihnen ihre neuen Waffen und Schilde einen entscheidenden Vorteil gegenüber dem Feind verschafften. Abgesehen davon entwickelte Shaka auch eine neuartige taktische Formation, die so genannte "Büffelhorn"-Formation, wobei sich die Streitkräfte in einem rechten und einem linken Flügel (bzw. Horn) neben der Hauptkampfgruppe aufstellten. Aufgabe der Hauptkampfgruppe war es, den Feind frontal anzugreifen, während die "Hörner" ihn von links und rechts umzingelten. Ein so von drei Seiten eingekesselter und zudem noch schlechter ausgerüsteter und bewaffneter Gegner hatte kaum eine Chance, den Angriffen der Zulu standzuhalten.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mit der mächtigsten Armee der Region im Rücken weitete Shaka seine Schreckensherrschaft auf die arglosen Nachbarstämme in Südafrika aus. Zu Anfang verfügte er bei seinen Eroberungsfeldzügen lediglich über eine eingeschränkte Truppenanzahl. Durch geschickte diplomatische Schachzüge und gezielte Attentate gelang es ihm jedoch, sehr schnell zahlreiche Bündnisse zu schließen und Vasallenherrscher auf seine Seite zu bringen, die seinen Einflussbereich auf ein enorm großes Gebiet ausweiteten - und ebenso schnell stieg auch die Stärke der Truppen unter seinem Kommando an. Wer sich Shaka in den Weg stellte, wurde gnadenlos niedergemetzelt. Auf der Flucht vor den Zulu verließen in den darauf folgenden zehn Jahren immer mehr Stämme die Region. Diese Völkerwanderung ist auch unter der Bezeichnung "Mfecane" bekannt, was so viel bedeutet wie Störung oder Zerstreuung.[PARAGRAPH:2]Shaka wurde zwar als großer Eroberer erachtet, nicht aber als tüchtiger Herrscher seines eigenen Volkes. Seine brutale Regentschaft war recht unpopulär und so wurden folgerichtig diverse Anschläge und Sturzversuche gegen ihn unternommen. Schließlich sollte dies im Jahr 1828 auch gelingen: Shaka wurde von seinen beiden Halbbrüdern erstochen. Noch im Sterben liegend, warnte er seine Halbbrüder, dass diese nicht lange über die Zulu herrschen würden und die weißen Männer bald kämen, um ihnen ihr Land zu nehmen. Zum Leidwesen der Zulu sollte Shaka damit wirklich Recht behalten, denn innerhalb der nächsten 70 Jahre wurden die Zulu tatsächlich von den Briten unterworfen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Es wäre interessant, zu wissen, was wohl passiert wäre, wenn Shaka zum Zeitpunkt des Einmarschs der Briten in das Zulureich noch gelebt hätte. Er war ohne Zweifel ein großer Militärreformer und vielleicht hätte er um einiges früher die Macht der britischen Schusswaffen erkannt - möglicherweise sogar versucht, sehr schnell welche aufzutreiben, um seine eigenen Truppen damit auszurüsten. Dennoch hätte sein Volk nach wie vor nicht auf eine fundierte wirtschaftliche Grundlage zurückgreifen können und kaum eine Möglichkeit gehabt, solche Waffen einzukaufen. Vielleicht hätte er Kämpfe auf offenem Gelände vermieden und stattdessen Guerilla-Taktiken angewendet - dies hätte den Invasoren das Leben sicherlich deutlich schwerer gemacht -, aber am Ende wäre vermutlich wohl auch Shaka von der schweren Militärmaschinerie der Briten überrollt worden.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Shaka[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Capitano zulu[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vissuto nel:[\BOLD] 1787 - 1828[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Shaka fu il capitano zulu al quale si attribuisce la trasformazione della propria tribù da entità insignificante a vero terrore dell'Africa meridionale. Molti storici lo considerano un genio militare. Nel corso della sua tumultuosa vita, Shaka rivoluzionò la società zulu e alterò profondamente il corso della storia della sua tribù per sempre.[PARAGRAPH:2]Shaka nacque intorno al 1787 ed era figlio del capo Senzangakona degli Zulu e di una donna di nome Nandi, figlia a sua volta di un capo di una tribù vicina. Sin da ragazzo Shaka combatté al servizio di un altro capitano della regione, Digiswayo. Quando suo padre morì, intorno al 1816, Shaka venne aiutato da Digiswayo a reclamare il potere tra gli Zulu. Per rendere maggiormente sicura la propria posizione, Shaka assassinò poi il fratellastro.[PARAGRAPH:2] Una volta al potere, Shaka avviò una serie di riforme che trasformarono l'esercito zulu in una forza inarrestabile nell'ambito della regione. Anzitutto, Shaka sostituì il tradizionale "assegai" (una lancia simile al giavellotto) con il "iklwa", una lancia più corta e adatta per il corpo a corpo, e introdusse l'utilizzo di uno scudo più grande e pesante. Questo nuovo equipaggiamento permise a Shaka di alterare profondamente le tattiche di battaglia del suo esercito e di cambiare la natura degli scontri nella sua regione.[PARAGRAPH:2]Prima di Shaka, infatti, gli scontri tra le tribù dell'Africa meridionale erano poco più che rituali. I due eserciti restavano a distanza, intonavano inni di guerra e sbattevano gli scudi mentre si scagliavano reciprocamente contro le lance finché una delle fazioni non avesse vacillato e si fosse ritirata, lasciando il campo all'altra. Pochi guerrieri venivano uccisi e raramente gli scontri avevano esito decisivo.[PARAGRAPH:2]Con le sue riforme militari, Shaka cambiò tutto questo. Egli insegnò ai suoi uomini ad avvicinarsi al nemico e a combattere in mischia, dove con le nuove armi i suoi uomini avrebbero avuto un notevole vantaggio tattico. Shaka inventò anche la formazione a "corna di bufalo", in cui l'esercito aveva dei fianchi pronunciati (le corna) a destra e a sinistra del corpo principale. Quest'ultimo aveva il compito di ingaggiare il nemico frontalmente, mentre le corna l'avrebbero attaccato ai fianchi. Circondate su tre fronti e con armi inadatte, poche armate riuscivano a sostenere un attacco degli Zulu.[PARAGRAPH:2]Alla guida del più potente esercito della regione, Shaka scatenò il terrore tra le altre tribù dell'Africa meridionale, colte alla sprovvista. Shaka iniziò le sue conquiste con forze limitate, ma grazie a un'abile opera diplomatica e a un efficiente uso dell'assassinio, creò in breve tempo un sistema di alleanze e di vassallaggio che gli permise di controllare un vasto territorio e un numero quindi più ampio di soldati. Coloro che gli si opponevano erano massacrati senza pietà. Nel giro di dieci anni, molte tribù si ritrovarono costrette a emigrare, abbandonando l'area in tutte le direzioni. Questo grande spostamento di genti divenne noto come Mfecane, o "la dispersione".[PARAGRAPH:2]Grande conquistatore, Shaka non era però un buon sovrano interno. Il suo regime brutale era alquanto impopolare e vi furono diversi attentati e tentativi di colpi di stato finché uno non riuscì: nel 1828 Shaka fu ferito a morte dai suoi due fratellastri. Pare che in punto di morte avesse profetizzato loro che non avrebbero governato a lungo e che gli uomini bianchi presto avrebbero occupato le terre degli Zulu. Purtroppo per gli Zulu, Shaka aveva ragione: nel giro di settant'anni gli Zulu sarebbero stati conquistati dai Britannici.[PARAGRAPH:2]Potrebbe essere interessante immaginare cosa sarebbe successo se Shaka fosse stato ancora vivo all'arrivo dei Britannici in Zululand. Shaka fu un grande innovatore militare e forse avrebbe compreso molto prima l'importanza dei fucili inglesi e cercato di adottarli anche lui. Rimane però il fatto che il suo popolo non aveva la base industriale necessaria per produrli né molti mezzi per acquistarli. Avrebbe potuto evitare allora gli scontri campali e adottare una tattica da guerriglia, ma anche se questo avesse provocato più morti tra gli invasori, probabilmente non sarebbe bastato per sconfiggere l'inarrestabile macchina militare britannica.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Chaka[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Líder zulú[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] 1787 - 1828[NEWLINE][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Chaka era un líder zulú a quien se atribuye el mérito de haber logrado que su tribu pasara de ser una de tantas entidades insignificantes al terror del sur de África. Muchos historiadores lo consideran además un genio militar. Durante su tumultuosa vida, provocó cambios revolucionarios en la sociedad zulú y es muy probable que alterara la historia de su tribu para siempre.[PARAGRAPH:2]Chaka nació alrededor del año 1787, hijo del jefe zulú Senzangakona y de Nandi, que era a su vez hija de un caudillo de una tribu cercana. En su juventud, sirvió como guerrero a otro jefe llamado Digiswayo. Cuando su padre murió, alrededor de 1816, Digiswayo le ayudó a reclamar el título de jefe de los zulúes. A continuación, Chaka envenenó a su hermanastro para asegurarse el trono.[PARAGRAPH:2] Una vez tuvo el control de los zulúes, inició una serie de reformas que transformarían al ejército de su tribu en la fuerza más poderosa de la región. Para empezar, reemplazó la "assegai" tradicional (una lanza arrojadiza parecida a una jabalina) por la "iklwa", un venablo corto que se usaba cuerpo a cuerpo. Además equipó a sus soldados con escudos más grandes y pesados. Este nuevo armamento le permitió alterar de manera total las tácticas de su ejército y cambiar la forma de hacer la guerra en la región.[PARAGRAPH:2]Antes de Chaka, el combate entre las tribus del sur de África era una práctica muy ritualizada. Las dos fuerzas se mantenían a cierta distancia mientras entonaban cánticos, golpeaban sus escudos y se arrojaban las lanzas. Al cabo de algún tiempo, uno de los bandos terminaría por cansarse y se retiraría, con lo que el campo de batalla quedaría en poder del otro. Morían muy pocos guerreros y las batallas no solían resultar decisivas.[PARAGRAPH:2]Con sus reformas militares, Chaka cambió todo esto. Enseñó a sus fuerzas a aproximarse al ejecito enemigo y buscar el cuerpo a cuerpo con sus adversarios, donde sus nuevas lanzas y escudos les proporcionaban una ventaja decisiva con respecto a sus enemigos. Además, inventó una formación táctica llamada "cuernos de búfalo" en la que su ejército tenía unas alas (o "cuernos") muy largas que se extendían a derecha e izquierda del contingente principal. El centro trababa batalla directamente con el enemigo, mientras que los cuernos lo flanqueaban por la derecha y la izquierda. Rodeados por tres lados y enfrentados a un enemigo armado con mejores armas y escudos, pocos ejércitos podían hacer frente a un ataque zulú.[PARAGRAPH:2]Con el ejército más poderoso de la región bajo su mando, Chaka desencadenó un reinado de terror sobre las desprevenidas tribus vecinas del sur de África. Inició sus conquistas con fuerzas muy limitadas. Sin embargo, empleando la diplomacia y un hábil uso del asesinato, estableció rápidamente un sistema de alianzas y gobernantes vasallos que le permitió extender su control sobre un gran territorio e incrementar las fuerzas a su disposición. Quienes se le oponían fueron masacrados sin piedad. Antes de una década, las tribus empezaron a emigrar en todas direcciones huyendo de los zulúes. Este movimiento de pueblos se conoce hoy día como el Mfecane o "la desbandada".[PARAGRAPH:2]Aunque Chaka fue un gran conquistador, no fue tan bueno como gobernante. Su brutal régimen era bastante impopular y hubo numerosos intentos de golpe de estado y asesinato. Finalmente, uno de ellos tuvo éxito cuando, en 1828, Chaka fue herido de muerte por sus dos hermanastros. Se dice que, mientras agonizaba, Chaka aseguró a sus hermanos que no gobernarían mucho tiempo y que los blancos conquistarían muy pronto las tierras de los zulúes. Por desgracia para ellos, decía la verdad, y antes de que hubieran transcurrido setenta años, los zulúes serían conquistados por los británicos.[PARAGRAPH:2]Es interesante especular con lo que habría ocurrido si Chaka hubiera estado vivo cuando los británicos invadieron Zululandia. Chaka era un gran innovador militar y es posible que hubiese entendido muy pronto la potencia de los rifles británicos y hubiese tratado de introducir el uso de esta arma entre sus tropas. No obstante, es un hecho que su pueblo carecía de base industrial y de posibilidades de importar armas de fuego a gran escala. Puede que se hubiese decantado por librar una guerra de guerrillas; aunque habría causado grandes contratiempos a los invasores, lo más probable es que hubiese acabado por ser derrotado por la maquinaria militar-industrial del coloso británico.

TEXT.English: [H1]Shivaji Bhonsle[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of the Marathas[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1630 - 1680 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj (19 February 1630 - 3 April 1680), was a Maratha sovereign who founded the Maratha Empire, which, at its peak, covered much of the Indian subcontinent, encompassing a territory of over 2.8 million square km. Shivaji as an aristocrat of the royal Bhosle clan led a resistance to free the Maratha people from the Sultanate of Bijapur and the Mughal Empire and established a Hindavi Swarajya ("self-rule of Hindu people"). He created an independent Maratha kingdom with Raigad as its capital. He was crowned as Chhatrapati ("sovereign") of the Maratha empire in 1674.[PARAGRAPH:2]He established a competent and progressive civil rule with the help of a well-regulated and disciplined military and well-structured administrative organizations. He also innovated rules of military engagement, pioneering the "Shiva sutra" or ganimi kava (guerrilla tactics), which leveraged strategic factors like geography, speed, surprise and focused pinpoint attacks to defeat his larger and more powerful enemies. From a small contingent of 2,000 soldiers inherited from his father, he created a formidable force of 100,000 soldiers. He built and restored forts located strategically inland and on seashores for secure lands and coastline. He revived ancient Hindu political tradition and court conventions, and promoted Marathi and Sanskrit in court and administration usage.

[H1]Sitting Bull[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]War Chief of the Hunkpapa Sioux[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] c.1830 - 1890 AD[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Sitting Bull, whose name in Lakota, Tatanka Yotanka, roughly translates to "an Obstinate Bull Buffalo at Rest," was born into the Hunkpapa Sioux branch of the Lakota tribe around 1830 AD. Rising to the position of Chief in 1856, Sitting Bull was a key member of the native resistance against American encroachment into the Black Hills of the Dakota Territory.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sitting Bull was a precocious youth, taking to warfare and hunting like a fish to water. At ten, he slew his first buffalo. By the time he had reached middle adolescence, Sitting Bull had been inducted into the prestigious societies of the Strong Heart Warrior and the Silent Eater. A most dangerous and powerful warrior - despite walking with a limp from a bullet wound he suffered as a youth - Sitting Bull became a feared name among the Lakota, the young Chief leading his fellow Hunkpapa into numerous victories over other tribes.[PARAGRAPH:1]His expertise in warfare did not keep Sitting Bull from signing the Fort Laramie Treaty of 1868, which called for the halting of American expansion into Sioux territory beyond the Powder River. But with the discovery of gold in the Black Hills in 1874, a new rush of colonists from the East began violating the treaty. Sitting Bull is said to have had a prophetic dream regarding the American expansion - an American military officer and his men, plummeting from the sky into a Sioux village - which was interpreted as a portent of the Americans' imminent doom. Not long after Sitting Bull's vision, General George Custer and his seventh cavalry launched an attack on a native village, only to be decimated by the assembled Sioux and Cheyenne fighters.[PARAGRAPH:1]American wrath quickly fell upon Sitting Bull and his people, and they were forced to flee to Canada where, despite a reception worthy of a foreign dignitary, they were to remain but briefly. A dearth of resources in their new lands threatened the Lakota with starvation, forcing Sitting Bull to guide his people back to the United States in 1881, with the understanding that they would receive land, sustenance and peace in America.[PARAGRAPH:1]Upon his return to the United States, Sitting Bull and a number of his followers joined Buffalo Bill Cody's Wild West show. Cody was able to provide a better standard of living than Sitting Bull and his Sioux brethren could expect to receive on the reservations to which they were now assigned, and a strong friendship formed between Cody and the native leader.[PARAGRAPH:1]In the final decade of the nineteenth century, the "Ghost Dance," a ritual promising to rid the natives of American influence once and for all, began to spread among the Sioux. Tensions again grew between the Lakota and the American military, who had expressly forbade native religious rituals like the "Ghost Dance." Buffalo Bill stepped in to try and negotiate a peaceful truce, but none was to be had. Fearing Sitting Bull's involvement in the growing ritual, the Chief was arrested and assassinated by Indian policemen in 1890, just days before the American opposition to the "Ghost Dance" would bring about the infamous Massacre at Wounded Knee.
TEXT.French: [H1]Sitting Bull[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Chef de guerre des Sioux Hunkpapas[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates :[\BOLD]1830 (approx.) - 1890 ap. J.C.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Sitting Bull, dont le nom en Lakota, Tatanka Yotanka, se traduit par "Taureau obstiné au repos," naquit vers 1830 au sein des Sioux Hunkpapas de la tribu Lakota. Accédant au statut de chef en 1856, Sitting Bull fut un membre clé de la résistance amérindienne contre l'appropriation américaine des Black Hills, dans le territoire du Dakota.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sitting Bull est un jeune homme précoce, passionné par la guerre et la chasse. A dix ans, il tue son premier bison. Lorsqu'il atteint l'adolescence, Sitting Bull fait déjà partie des prestigieuses sociétés Strong Heart Warrior et Silent Eater. Redoutable et puissant guerrier (malgré le fait qu'il boite suite à une blessure par balle) Sitting Bull devient un chef respecté parmi les Lakota. Ce jeune chef conduit les Hunkpapas à la victoire sur plusieurs autres tribus.[PARAGRAPH:1]Son expertise martiale n'empêche pas Sitting Bull de signer le traité de Fort Laramie en 1868, qui exige l'arrêt de l'expansion américaine en territoire sioux au-delà du fleuve Powder. Mais avec la découverte d'or dans les Black Hills en 1874, une nouvelle ruée de colons venus de l'est violent le traité. On raconte que Sitting Bull aurait eu un songe concernant l'expansion américaine (un officier américain et ses hommes tombant du ciel dans un village sioux) et ce dernier est interprété comme un présage de leur victoire sur les Américains. Peu après le songe de Sitting Bull, le général George Custer lance une attaque contre un village indien, mais sa septième cavalerie est décimée par les guerriers sioux et cheyennes[PARAGRAPH:1]La colère américaine s'abat sur Sitting Bull et son peuple et ils sont contraints de fuir au Canada où, malgré un accueil digne d'une haute personnalité étrangère, ils ne restent que peu de temps. Menacée de famine, la tribu de Sitting Bull est forcée de repartir pour les Etats-Unis en 1881, après avoir reçu la promesse qu'ils y trouveraient des terres, de la nourriture et la paix.[PARAGRAPH:1]De retour aux Etats-Unis, Sitting Bull et certains des membres de sa tribu rejoignent le Wild West Show de Buffalo Bill Cody. Cody leur fournit une meilleure qualité de vie que celle qui les attend dans les réserves dans lesquelles ils sont parqués, et une forte amitié se noue entre Cody et le chef amérindien.[PARAGRAPH:1]Dans les dix dernières années du dix-neuvième siècle, la " Danse des Fantômes," rituel promettant aux amérindiens de se débarrasser une fois pour toute de l'influence américaine, commence à se propager parmi les Sioux. Les tensions reprennent entre les Lakota et l'armée américaine, qui a expressément interdit les rituels religieux amérindiens tels que la "Danse des Fantômes". Buffalo Bill essaie de négocier une issue pacifique, en vain. Craignant l'implication de Sitting Bull dans la propagation de ce rituel, le chef est arrêté et assassiné par des policiers indiens en 1890, quelques jours avant que l'opposition américaine à la "Danse des Fantômes" ne provoque le terrible massacre de Wounded Knee.
TEXT.German: [H1]Sitting Bull[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Kriegshäuptling der Hunkpapa-Sioux[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] ca. 1830 - 1890 n. Chr.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Sitting Bull, dessen Name auf Lakota, Tatanka Yotanka, grob übersetzt "ein sturer Büffel, der sich ausruht" bedeutet, wurde im Hunkpapa-Sioux-Zweig des Lakota-Stammes um ungefähr 1830 n. Chr. geboren. Sitting Bull stieg 1856 zum Häuptling auf und war eine Schlüsselfigur im Widerstand der Indianer gegen das amerikanische Eindringen in die Black Hills auf Dakota-Gebiet.[PARAGRAPH:1]Sitting Bull war ein frühreifer Junge, und das Handwerk des Kriegers und Jägers schien wie für ihn geschaffen. Mit zehn Jahren erlegte er seinen ersten Büffel. Als er die mittleren Jahre seiner Jugend erreicht hatte, war Sitting Bull in die angesehenen Gesellschaften der Strong Heart Warriors und der Silent Eaters eingeführt worden. Er war ein äußerst gefährlicher und mächtiger Krieger - obwohl er hinkte, seit er als junger Mann eine Schussverletzung erlitten hatte - und der Name Sitting Bull war unter den Lakota gefürchtet, da der junge Häuptling seine Hunkpapa-Brüder zu zahlreichen Siegen über andere Stämme führte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Trotz seiner kriegerischen Erfahrung unterzeichnete Sitting Bull 1868 den Vertrag von Fort Laramie, der die Beendigung der amerikanischen Ausbreitung in das Sioux-Gebiet jenseits des Powder River forderte. Doch als 1874 in den Black Hills Gold gefunden wurde, begann ein neuer Zustrom von Siedlern, den Vertrag zu verletzen. Sitting Bull soll einen Zukunftstraum über die amerikanische Expansion gehabt haben - ein amerikanischer Militäroffizier und seine Männer, die vom Himmel in ein Dorf der Sioux fielen - der als Vorzeichen des bevorstehenden Untergangs der Amerikaner interpretiert wurde. Nicht lange nach Sitting Bulls Vision griffen General George Custer und seine Siebte Kavallerie ein Indianerdorf an und wurden von den versammelten Sioux- und Cheyenne-Kriegern völlig vernichtet.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der amerikanische Zorn fiel rasch auf Sitting Bull und sein Volk, und sie waren gezwungen, nach Kanada zu fliehen, wo sie trotz eines Empfangs, der eines ausländischen Würdenträgers würdig war, nur kurze Zeit blieben. Ein Mangel an Ressourcen in ihrem neuen Land bedrohte die Lakota mit dem Hungertod, und Sitting Bull war gezwungen, sein Volk 1881 zurück in die USA zu führen, wo man ihnen Land, Nahrung und Frieden in Amerika versprochen hatte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nach seiner Rückkehr in die Vereinigten Staaten schlossen sich Sitting Bull und eine Schar seiner Anhänger Buffalo Bill Codys Wild-West-Show an. Cody war in der Lage, Sitting Bull und seinen Sioux-Brüdern einen besseren Lebensstandard zu bieten, als sie in den ihnen zugewiesenen Reservaten zu erwarten hatten, und zwischen Cody und dem indianischen Anführer entstand eine feste Freundschaft.[PARAGRAPH:1]Im letzten Jahrzehnt des 19. Jahrhunderts verbreitete sich der "Geistertanz" (ein Ritual, das die Indianer für alle Zeiten vom amerikanischen Einfluss befreien sollte) unter den Sioux. Es kam zu vermehrten Spannungen zwischen den Lakota und dem amerikanischen Militär, das alle indianischen religiösen Zeremonien, und somit auch den "Geistertanz", ausdrücklich verboten hatte. Buffalo Bill mischte sich ein und versuchte, einen friedlichen Kompromiss auszuhandeln, scheiterte jedoch. Da man Sitting Bulls mögliche Beteiligung an dem beliebter werdenden Ritual befürchtete, wurde der Häuptling von indianischen Polizisten 1890 verhaftet und ermordet, nur wenige Tage, ehe der amerikanische Widerstand gegen den "Geistertanz" das berüchtigte Massaker am Wounded Knee verursachen sollte.
TEXT.Italian: [H1]Toro Seduto[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Capo dei Sioux Hunkpapa[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vita:[\BOLD] ca. 1830 - 1890 d.C.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Storia:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Toro Seduto, il cui nome in Lakota, Tatanka Yotanka, significa pressappoco "un bisonte maschio imbronciato che riposa", nacque nel ramo Sioux Hunkpapa della tribù Lakota attorno al 1830 d.C. arrivato a posizione di capo nel 1856, Toro Seduto fu un membro chiave della resistenza dei nativi contro la colonizzazione americana nelle Black Hills del territorio Dakota.[PARAGRAPH:1]Toro Seduto era un giovane precoce, che imparò l'arte della guerra e della caccia con molta facilità. A dieci anni uccise il suo primo bisonte e a metà dell'adolescenza entrò a far parte delle società guerriere dei Cuori Forti e dei Mangiatori Silenziosi. Toro Seduto era un formidabile guerriero, nonostante zoppicasse per una ferita da proiettile subita da giovane, e divenne molto temuto tra i Lakota: il giovane capo condusse, infatti, i propri Hunkpapa a numerose vittorie su altre tribù.[PARAGRAPH:1]La sua esperienza in guerra non impedì a Toro Seduto di firmare il Trattato di Fort Laramie nel 1868, che cercava di porre un freno all'espansione americana nei territori Sioux oltre il Powder River. Ma con la scoperta dell'oro nelle Black Hills, nel 1874, un'ondata di coloni in arrivo da est cominciò a violare il trattato. Si dice che Toro Seduto ebbe un sogno profetico riguardante l'espansione americana: un ufficiale americano e i suoi uomini che cadevano dal cielo in un villaggio Sioux e questo fu interpretato come un segno dell'imminente fato degli americani. Non molto dopo la visione di Toro Seduto, il generale George Custer e il suo settimo cavalleggeri lanciarono un attacco contro un villaggio di nativi, ma vennero decimati dai guerrieri Sioux e Cheyenne.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ben presto l'ira americana si abbatté su Toro Seduto e la sua gente, che furono costretti a fuggire in Canada dove, nonostante un'accoglienza degna di un dignitario straniero, rimasero ben poco. La scarsità di risorse nelle nuove terre minacciava di far soffrire la fame ai Lakota e così nel 1881 Toro Seduto fu costretto a guidarli nuovamente negli Stati Uniti dove avrebbero dovuto vivere in pace ricevendo terra e aiuti.[PARAGRAPH:1]Al ritorno negli USA, Toro Seduto e alcuni suoi seguaci si unirono al Wild West Show di Bill Cody, che fu in grado di garantire loro uno standard di vita superiore rispetto a quello che li avrebbe attesi nelle riserve a cui erano stati assegnati, e tra Cody e il capo indiano nacque una forte amicizia.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nell'ultimo decennio del diciannovesimo secolo cominciò a diffondersi tra i Sioux un rituale chiamato "Danza degli Spettri", che prometteva di liberare i nativi dall'influenza degli americani una volta per tutte. Ancora una volta crebbero le tensioni tra i Lakota e l'esercito americano, che aveva espressamente proibito rituali religiosi come quello della "Danza degli Spettri". Buffalo Bill provò a negoziare una tregua pacifica, ma non ci riuscì. Siccome si temeva un suo coinvolgimento nel rituale, Toro Seduto fu arrestato e assassinato nel 1890 da poliziotti indiani, solo pochi giorni prima che l'opposizione americana alla "Danza degli Spettri" portasse al terribile Massacro di Wounded Knee.
TEXT.Spanish: [H1]Toro Sentado[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Caudillo de los sioux hunkpapa[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Vivió:[\BOLD] c. 1830 - 1890 d. C.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Biografía:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Toro Sentado (cuyo nombre en lakota, Tatanka Yotanka, puede traducirse aproximadamente como "un búfalo tozudo descansando") nació en la rama sioux hunkpapa de la tribu lakota en torno al año 1830 d. C. Tras ascender a la posición de caudillo en 1856, Toro Sentado se consolidó como elemento clave de la resistencia de los nativos frente a la colonización de las Colinas Negras de Dakota por parte de los blancos.[PARAGRAPH:1]Toro Sentado fue un joven muy precoz, que se desenvolvía como pez en el agua tanto en la guerra como en la caza. A los diez años mató su primer búfalo. Al llegar a la adolescencia ya pertenecía a las prestigiosas sociedades del Guerrero del corazón fuerte y el Devorador silencioso. Guerrero fuerte y letal a pesar de la cojera que arrastraba desde que en su juventud recibiera un balazo, Toro Sentado consiguió que su nombre se convirtiera en sinónimo de terror entre los lakota al conducir a sus hermanos hunkpapa en numerosas victorias sobre otras tribus.[PARAGRAPH:1]Su destreza como guerrero no le impidió firmar el tratado de Fuerte Laramie (1868), que en teoría debía poner fin a la expansión de los blancos por territorio sioux más allá de Powder River. Pero el descubrimiento de oro en las Colinas Negras (1874), provocó que una nueva oleada de colonos del este empezara violar el tratado. Se dice que Toro Sentado tuvo un sueño profético sobre el futuro, en el que un oficial blanco descendía junto con sus hombres sobre una aldea sioux, sueño que se interpretó como presagio de la inminente ruina de los blancos. Poco después de este sueño, el general George Custer, a la cabeza de setenta hombres, atacó una aldea india, pero en el camino de regreso su destacamento fue aniquilado por los guerreros sioux y cheyenne.[PARAGRAPH:1]La furia de los blancos no tardó en descargarse sobre Toro Sentado y su pueblo, que se vieron obligados a escapar a Canadá. Sin embargo, a pesar de un recibimiento digno de una delegación diplomática extranjera, solo permanecerían en este país breve tiempo. La escasez de los recursos en sus nuevas tierras amenazaba a los lakota con el fantasma del hambre, y obligó a Toro Sentado a regresar a los Estados Unidos en 1881, bajo una promesa de tierra, alimentos y paz.[PARAGRAPH:1]Tras su regreso a los Estados Unidos, Toro Sentado y algunos de sus seguidores se unieron al show del salvaje oeste de Buffalo Bill Cody. Cody pudo ofrecer a Toro Sentado y sus sioux un nivel de vida muy superior al que les esperaba en las reservas a las que habían sido asignados, y de este modo se formaron fuertes vínculos de amistad entre Cody y el líder indio.[PARAGRAPH:1]En la última década del siglo XIX, empezó a ganar popularidad entre los sioux la "danza espectral", un ritual que prometía acabar con la influencia de los blancos sobre los nativos de una vez para siempre. Las tensiones volvieron a aumentar entre los lakota y el ejército estadounidense, que había prohibido los rituales religiosos de los nativos como la "danza espectral". Buffalo Bill intentó ejercer como mediador y negociar una tregua, pero fue en vano. Temiendo la influencia de Toro Sentado en el joven movimiento, la policía india arrestó y asesinó al jefe en 1890, días antes de que la oposición de los blancos a la "danza espectral" desembocara en la infame masacre de Wounded Knee.

TEXT.English: [H1]Jan III Sobieski[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]King of Poland, Grand Duke of Lithuania[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1629 - 1696 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Jan (John) Sobieski was born 1629 at Olesko, Poland, to Jakub (James) Sobieski (1580-1646), Voivod of the Ruthenian Voivodship and Castellan of Krakow and Zofia Teofillia (Danilowicz), granddaughter of Hetman Stanislaw Zebewski. He had won fame as an outstanding military commander in wars against the Ottomans, Tatars, Muscovites, Cossacks and Swedes.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1665 he became Great Marshal of the Crown, and in 1666 Field Crown Hetman. In 1668 he was appointed by King Jan II Kazimierz the Great Crown Hetman and Commander-in-Chief of the Polish Army. After a distinguished military career, and following the death of Jan II Kazimierz's successor, Michal Korybut Wisniowiecki, Sobieski was on May 21, 1674, elected by the szlachta (nobility) to be King of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, and was crowned February 2, 1676.[PARAGRAPH:2]Jan Sobieski's military prowess, demonstrated in war against the Ottoman Empire, contributed to his election as King of Poland. One of his ambitions was to unify Christian Europe in a crusade to drive the Turks out of Europe. He made alliance with the Holy Roman Emperor and joined the Holy League initiated by Pope Innocent XI to preserve Christendom.[PARAGRAPH:2]Sobieski planned to occupy Prussia with Swedish cooperation and French support. This undertaking was doomed because of war with Turkey and the opposition of the Commonwealth's magnates.[PARAGRAPH:2]Sobieski's greatest success came September 12, 1683, with his victory at the Battle of Vienna, in command of Polish, Austrian and German troops, against the Turks under Kara Mustafa. The Pope and other foreign dignitaries hailed Sobieski as the "Savior of Vienna and Western European civilization." In a letter to his wife he wrote, "All the common people kissed my hands, my feet, my clothes; others only touched me, saying: 'Ah, let us kiss so valiant a hand!'"[PARAGRAPH:2]Upon reaching Vienna, he joined up with the Austrians and Germans. Sobieski planned to attack on the 13th of September, but he had noticed that the Turkish resistance was weak and ordered full attack on September 12, 1683. At 4:00 a.m. Sobieski's army of about 81,000 men attacked a Turkish army that numbered about 130,000. Sobieski charged with husaria forward and soon after the Turkish battle line was broken as the Turks scattered in confusion. At 5:30 p.m., Sobieski entered the deserted tent of Kara Mustafa and the battle of Vienna was over.[PARAGRAPH:2]King Jan III Sobieski, nicknamed by the Turks the "Lion of Lechistan", and the last great king of Poland, died in Wilan, Poland on June 17, 1696. His wife, Maria Kasimira, died in 1716 in Blois, France and her body was returned to Poland. They are interred together in Wawel Castle, Krakow, Poland.
TEXT.German: [H1]Johann III. Sobieski[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]König von Polen[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 1629 - 1696 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Johann III. Sobieski (polnisch Jan III Sobieski, litauisch Jonas Sobieskis) war ein polnischer Adeliger, Staatsmann, Feldherr und ab 1674, als König von Polen und Großfürst von Litauen, der gewählte Herrscher des Staates Polen-Litauen, aus dem Adelsgeschlecht der Sobieskis. Er gilt als der Retter Wiens während der Zweiten Wiener Türkenbelagerung, da er bei der Schlacht am Kahlenberg am 12. September 1683 mit seiner Hussaria den entscheidenden Angriff gegen die Türken führte.[PARAGRAPH:2]Johann (Jan) entstammte dem polnischen Hochadelsgeschlecht der Sobieskis, das der Wappengemeinschaft Janina angehörte. Er war Sohn des Kastellans von Krakau Jakub Sobieski und der Sofia-Teofila aus dem Haus Danilowicz, und über sie Urenkel des Stanislaw Zólkiewski. In seiner Kindheit erfuhr er eine sorgfältige Schulbildung an Polens ältester Schule, dem Collegium Nowodworskiego. Von 1640 bis 1647 studierte er an der Jagiellonen Universität in Krakau.[PARAGRAPH:2]Im Osmanisch-Polnischem Krieg von 1672-1676 gelang ihm der Entsatz der Stadt Chotyn durch einen Sieg am 11. November 1673 gegen das Heer des Großwesirs Köprülü Fazil Ahmed.[NEWLINE]Am 21. Mai 1674 wurde er nach dem Tode des Königs Michaels I. auf den polnischen Thron gewählt. Nicht zuletzt hatte ihm seine profranzösische Haltung und seine ehrgeizige Ehegattin mit guten Beziehungen zum französischen Königshof zur Königskrone verholfen. 1676 willigte er in den Vertrag von Zurawno ein, der den Krieg mit für das erschöpfte Polen ungünstigen Bedingungen vorläufig beendete.[PARAGRAPH:2]König Jan III. Sobieski beherrschte mehrere Sprachen, war ein großer Kunstliebhaber und Mäzen. Sein Palast in Wilanów wird für eine der größten Errungenschaften des polnischen Barockstils gehalten. Eine weitere Residenz hatte er im Schloss von Schowkwa. Seine Briefe an seine Frau Marie sind ebenfalls große Zeugnisse polnischer Epistolografie. Er starb 1696 in der königlichen Residenz in Wilanów bei Warschau und ist auf dem Wawel in Krakau begraben. Es folgte ihm nicht sein Sohn Jakob Louis Heinrich Sobieski auf dem Thron, sondern August der Starke, der Kurfürst von Sachsen. Seine Tochter Therese Kunigunde war mit dem Kurfürsten Maximilian II. Emanuel von Bayern verheiratet.

TEXT.English: [H1]Songzan Ganbu[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Emperor of Tibet[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 617 - 649 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Songtsen Gampo was the first Dharmaraja of Tibet. He married a Nepalese and a Chinese princess and was famous for building the Jokhang Temple of Lhasa which still stands today.[PARAGRAPH:2]Songtsen Gampo was the forefather of Buddhism in Tibet. Two generations before King Trisong Detsen invited Shantarakshita and Padmasambhava to Tibet, King Songtsen Gampo cultivated the nation for its transformation, clearing pathways for the dharma to enter and ultimately permeate Tibetan culture. Without Songsten Gampo there would be no Tibetan alphabet, Lhasa would have no Jokang, and the supreme demoness of Central Tibet might still be roaming the earth unfettered.[PARAGRAPH:2]Songtsen Gampo reigned from 617 to 650. His Yarlung dynasty was based in Central Tibet during an imperialist period in Tibetan history. Bon was the dominant religion, and Buddhism was only seminally present. No Tibetan translations of the Buddhist scriptures existed, partially because there was no written form of Tibetan, so Songsten Gampo instructed his minister Thonmi Sambota to travel to India, study Sanskrit, and develop a Tibetan script. He then commissioned the translation of several thousand texts.[PARAGRAPH:2]His celebrated successes in battle expanded the Tibetan empire deep into Nepal and China, and it was during these battles that he gained an appreciation of the neighbouring cultures. As a reminder of the great empire that Songtsen Gampo ruled, a large pillar still stands before the Potala palace in Lhasa, erected during his reign, on which is inscribed the agreement between the Tibetan and Chinese rulers to respect each other's borders. He studied Chinese, became skilled in the art of leadership, and most importantly, he adopted sacred codes of conduct from Buddhist scripture. Under his rule, sacred practices began to replace the shamanistic practices of the Bonpos.[PARAGRAPH:2]Songtsen Gampo's two queens can be credited for a great part of his cultural awareness. Bhirkuti, from Kathmandu, brought the traditions of Himalayan Buddhism. Princess Wengchen, daughter of the Tang emperor, brought a treasure trove of ancient Chinese wisdom. She travelled across the steppes to her husband with a collection of Chinese classic literature and texts on sacred astrology, geomancy, and medicine.[PARAGRAPH:2]Many obstacles lay in Princess Wengchen's path as she headed to Yarlung. She had a vision of a gargantuan demoness who lay sprawled across the Himalayas, so large that one limb lay in Paro, Bhutan and another lay in Western Tibet. When she arrived in Yarlung, she shared her vision with her new husband. Recognizing the value of the treasures that his bride brought to him, as well as the importance of her vision, King Songsten Gampo commissioned thirteen demoness-subjugating temples across the land, built over the demoness's vital organs, ankles, wrists, and torso, forever binding her from wreaking havoc. The Lhasa Jokang was built over her heart center, and Wengchin's Buddha statue was placed inside, where it still resides. Other such temples are Trenduk Lhakhang in Tsetang and Paro Kyichu in Bhutan.[PARAGRAPH:2]King Songtsen Gampo is considered a human emanation of Avalokiteshvara, and he was the grandfather of King Trisong Detsen. Songtsen Gampo meditated for several years in a cave that is now at the core of Potala palace, and is revered for his great patronage of Buddhism.[PARAGRAPH:2]Through his enlightened leadership, the path was cleared for the dharma to be propagated throughout the provinces, and for Buddhism to flourish.

[H1]el-Haj Mohammed Soeharto[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]President of Indonesia[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1921 - 2008 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Haji Mohammad Soeharto, more commonly referred to as simply Soeharto (General Suharto in the English-speaking world), is a former Indonesian military and political leader. He served as a military officer in the Indonesian National Revolution, but is better known as the long-reigning second President of Indonesia, holding the office from 1967 to 1998.[PARAGRAPH:2]Suharto seized power from his predecessor, the first president of Indonesia Sukarno, through a mixture of force and political maneuvering against the backdrop of foreign and domestic unrest. Over the three decades of his "New Order" regime, Suharto constructed a strong central government along militarist lines. An ability to maintain stability and an avowedly anti-Communist stance won him the economic and diplomatic patronage of several Western governments in the era of the Cold War. For almost all of his three-decade rule, Indonesia experienced rapid industrialization and economic growth.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Suharto regime had won the favour of Western governments and institutions, however, in 1990's, its increasingly authoritarian and corrupt practices became a source of much discontent. After the 1990s brought end of the Cold War, Western concern over communism waned, and Suharto's human rights record came under greater international scrutiny. In 1991, the murder of East Timorese civilians in a Dili cemetery, also known as the "Santa Cruz Massacre", caused American attention to focus on its military relations with the Suharto regime and the question of Indonesia's occupation of East Timor. In 1992,this attention resulted in the Congress of the United States passing limitations on IMET assistance to the Indonesian military, over the objections of President George H.W. Bush. In 1993, under President Bill Clinton, the U.S. delegation to the UN Human Rights Commission helped pass a resolution expressing deep concern over Indonesian human rights violations in East Timor. The Indonesian invasion and occupation of East Timor has been called the worst instance of genocide (relative to population) since the Holocaust.[PARAGRAPH:2]His almost unquestioned authority over Indonesian affairs slipped dramatically when the Asian financial crisis lowered Indonesians' standard of living and fractured his support among the nation's military, political and civil society institutions. After internal unrest and diplomatic isolation sapped his support in the mid-to-late 1990s, Suharto was forced to resign from the presidency in May 1998.[PARAGRAPH:2]After serving as the public face of Indonesia for over 30 years, Suharto then lived his post-presidential years in virtual seclusion. His legacy remains hotly debated and contested both in Indonesia and in foreign-policy debates in the West. Since his resignation, Suharto retired to a family compound in Central Jakarta, making few public appearances. Efforts to prosecute Suharto have mostly centered around alleged mismanagement of funds, and their force has been blunted due to health concerns. In january 2008, Suharto was taken to the Pertamina hospital, Jakarta, with complications arising from a weak heart, swelling of limbs and stomach, and partial renal failure. He died there at 27th of January at 1:10 pm.

[H1]Suleiman I the Magnificent[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan of the Ottoman Empire[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lived:[\BOLD] 1494 - 1566 AD[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Suleiman I, known as "The Magnificent," "The Legislator" and "The Grand Turk," was the caliph of Islam and the sultan of the Ottoman Empire, taking the reigns of the Turkish kingdom in 1520 and ruling until his death in 1566.[PARAGRAPH:2]The only heir still breathing when his father Selim I passed on, Suleiman continued his father's tradition of expansion throughout the Middle East, creating a new level of prosperity within the empire. Suleiman's conquests reached from Baghdad to Egypt, making the Ottoman Empire the main channel through which the riches of the east could reach Europe. Ottoman naval supremacy in the Mediterranean further aided Suleiman's economic empire, the corsair Barbarossa sending innumerable European ships to the sea floor.[PARAGRAPH:2]It was this penchant for expansionism that struck fear into the heart of Europe. The Sultan's push northward took him as far as Hungary, where he found his progress stalled by the Hapsburg ruler Archduke Ferdinand I.[PARAGRAPH:2]While his territorial accomplishments were impressive, the Sultan did not ignore the culture of his homeland, Suleiman himself a skilled poet and fervent Muslim. Towards the end of his reign, Suleiman commissioned numerous new mosques of a previously unseen grandeur, designed by master architect, Sinan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Suleiman became well known in both the Christian west and the Muslim east, but for strikingly different reasons. Most Europeans envied the Sultan for the sheer opulence in which he lived. Celebrations of a previously unheard of grandeur were held at the Hippodrome in Istanbul. Rooms covered in gold, gems and the finest tapestries could be seen throughout the Sultan's palace at Topkapi.[PARAGRAPH:2]Muslims, on the other hand, respected the Sultan for his belief in the rule of law. The Sultan adopted Islamic sacred law to compliment the traditional law already in place from his predecessors. Both Christian and Muslim recognized the renewed strength and sense of honor that Suleiman brought to the Ottoman Empire, deeming him worthy of the title "The Magnificent."
TEXT.French: [H1]Soliman Ier[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan de l'empire ottoman[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Dates:[\BOLD] 1494 - 1566 ap. J.C.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Biographie :[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Soliman Ier, connu sous le nom de "Soliman le Magnifique," ou "Le Législateur" et "Le Grand Turc," a été calife d'islam et sultan de l'empire ottoman. Il s'empare du pouvoir en 1520 et règne jusqu'à sa mort en 1566.[PARAGRAPH:2]Seul héritier vivant à la mort de son père Selim, Soliman perpétue les traditions expansionnistes de son père à travers le Moyen-Orient, créant une nouvelle ère de prospérité pour l'empire. Les conquêtes de Soliman s'étendent de Bagdad à l'Egypte, faisant de l'empire ottoman le principal canal pour les richesses de l'Est en partance pour l'Europe. La suprématie navale ottomane en Méditerranée ajoute à la croissance économique de son empire et le corsaire Barberousse envoie d'innombrables vaisseaux européens par le fond.[PARAGRAPH:2]C'est ce penchant pour l'expansionnisme qui effraie l'Europe. La percée vers le nord du sultan le mène jusqu'en Hongrie, où son avancée est stoppée par l'archiduc Ferdinand Ier.[PARAGRAPH:2]Même si ses conquêtes territoriales sont impressionnantes, le sultan, étant lui-même un poète de grand talent et un fervent musulman, est très sensible à la culture de son pays. Vers la fin de son règne, Soliman commande de nombreuses mosquées d'une magnificence inédite, conçues par son maître architecte, Sinan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Soliman devient célèbre à travers l'ouest catholique et l'est musulman, mais pour des raisons complètement différentes. La plupart des européens envient le sultan pour l'opulence dans laquelle il vit. Des fêtes somptueuses sont données à l'hippodrome d'Istanbul. Son palais de Topkapi abrite des pièces entièrement recouvertes d'or, de pierres précieuses et de magnifiques tapisseries.[PARAGRAPH:2]Les musulmans, quant à eux, respectent sa croyance dans l'hégémonie de la loi. Le sultan adopte la loi sacrée islamique pour succéder à la loi traditionnelle instaurée par ses prédécesseurs. Enfin, catholiques et musulmans s'accordent à reconnaître la force et le sens de l'honneur que Soliman confère à l'empire ottoman et l'honorent du titre de "Magnifique".
TEXT.German: [H1]Süleyman I.[\H1][NEWLINE][BOLD]Sultan des Osmanischen Reiches[\BOLD][NEWLINE][BOLD]Lebte:[\BOLD] 1494 - 1566 n. Chr.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Hintergrund:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]Süleyman I., bekannt als "Der Prächtige", "Der Gesetzgeber" und "Großtürke", war Kalif des Islam und Sultan des Osmanischen Reiches und regierte das türkische Königreich von 1520 bis zu seinem Tod im Jahr 1566.[PARAGRAPH:2]Süleyman war beim Tod seines Vaters Selim I. der einzige noch lebende Erbe, setzte dessen expansive Tradition im ganzen Mittleren Osten fort, und schuf innerhalb des Reiches ein neues Maß an Wohlstand. Süleymans Eroberungen reichten von Bagdad bis nach Ägypten und machten das Osmanische Reich zum Hauptumschlagplatz für die Kostbarkeiten Asiens auf dem Weg nach Europa. Die Seehoheit der Osmanen im Mittelmeer trug ebenfalls zu Süleymans Wirtschaftsreich bei, und der Korsar Barbarossa schickte unzählige europäische Schiffe auf den Meeresboden.[PARAGRAPH:2]Es war jene Lust auf Expansion, die Europa erzittern ließ. Der nördliche Vorstoß des Sultans führte ihn bis nach Ungarn, wo sein Vordringen vom habsburgischen Herrscher Erzherzog Ferdinand I. aufgehalten wurde.[PARAGRAPH:2]Sein Zugewinn an Gebieten war zwar beeindruckend, doch ignorierte der Sultan keineswegs die Kultur seiner Heimat, da Süleyman selbst ein talentierter Dichter und gläubiger Muslime war.
